alert.note: Alert for Calhoun; Richland (South Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Warning issued January 06 at 5:14AM EST until January 10 at 2:42PM EST by NWS Columbia
info.description: ...The Flood Warning is extended for the following rivers in South Carolina... Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden affecting Calhoun and Richland Counties. Congaree River At Carolina Eastman affecting Calhoun, Lexington and Richland Counties. ...The Flood Warning continues for the following rivers in South Carolina... Saluda River At Chappells affecting Greenwood, Newberry and Saluda Counties. Enoree River At Whitmire affecting Newberry and Union Counties. Congaree River At Columbia affecting Lexington and Richland Counties. ...FLOOD WARNING NOW IN EFFECT UNTIL EARLY TUESDAY AFTERNOON... * WHAT...Minor flooding is occurring and minor flooding is forecast. * WHERE...Congaree River At Congaree National Park-Gadsden. * WHEN...Until early Tuesday afternoon. * IMPACTS...At 17.0 feet, The access road to the Sandy Run subdivision becomes flooded. The lower boardwalk in the Congaree National Park becomes flooded by Cedar Creek. At 18.0 feet, Several homes in the Sandy Run subdivision along the river become flooded. At 18 feet the river covers the Weston Lake overlook in the Congaree National Park. Between 18 and 18.5 feet the river begins to cover sections of the elevated boardwalk. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 4:00 AM EST Friday the stage was 17.2 feet. - Recent Activity...The maximum river stage in the 24 hours ending at 4:00 AM EST Friday was 17.2 feet. - Forecast...The river is expected to rise to a crest of 17.6 feet this evening. It will then fall below flood stage early Monday afternoon. - Flood stage is 15.0 feet. - http://www.floodsafety.noaa.gov &&
info.instruction: Report any flooding directly to the Columbia National Weather Service at 803 234 4115 when it is safe to do so. You can also send reports by Facebook or Twitter to NWSColumbia or by e-mail at NWS.Columbia@noaa.gov. Caution is urged when walking near riverbanks. Residents and those with interests near the river should monitor rising water levels and take action if necessary. Additional information is available at www.weather.gov. The next statement will be issued this afternoon at 515 PM EST.
